title: 2015 Special  Part-2
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given real numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that 2015 is a root of "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^{2}(1-pq)-x(p^{2}+q^{2}) -(1+pq)=0,"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"we create 2015 numbers such that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(p, h_{1},h_{2},.........h_{2015}, q) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a harmonic progression."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \dfrac{h_{1}-h_{2015}}{pq(p-q)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

title: 2015 Sum Sequences
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can represent the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in various ways as the sum of positive consecutive integers:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"97+98+99+100+...+115=2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"502+503+504+505=2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of consecutive integers with the highest number of terms that result in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"12+13+14+15+16+17+...+61+62+63+64"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We need to add up "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"53"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" consecutive numbers to get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the highest number of positive consecutive integers that we can add to get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2015"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose the sequence is: n, n+1, n+2, ..., n+m-1.
So it sums to get the summary: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{m^2}{2}+\frac{m(2n-1)}{2}-2015=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
This equation has a positive root is: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{\frac{(2n-1)^2}{4}+2 \times 2015}-\frac{2n-1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
By checking n=1,2,3,..., easy to get n=2.
So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m=\boxed{62}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2015 Trig
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\bigtriangleup ABC "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the opposite sides of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\angle A "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\angle B "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\angle C "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" c "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" respectively. If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a^{2}+b^{2}=tc^{2}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\cot C=2015( \\cot  A+\\cot B) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find the value of the constant "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" t "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"  \cot C=2015 (\cot A+\cot B) \\
  \Rightarrow \frac {\cot C} {\cot A+\cot B} =2015 \\
 \Rightarrow \frac{\left ( \frac{\cos C}{\sin C} \right )}{\left ( \frac{\cos A}{\sin A}+\frac{\cos B}{\sin B} \right )}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{\frac{\cos C}{\sin C}}{\frac{\cos A}{\sin A}+\frac{\cos B}{\sin B}}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{\cos C}{\sin C}\times \frac{\sin A\cdot \sin B}{\sin (A+B)}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{\sin A\cdot \sin B\cdot \cos C}{\sin^{2}C}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{ab}{c^{2}}\cdot \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2ab}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(note that the above step is due to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2c^{2}}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \frac{t-1}{2}=2015 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \boxed{t=4031}. "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            (In response to Challenge Master:) The question gives information about relationship among the sides of a triangle, so I thought we may use trig identities related to the sides. They include the sine and cosine rules. The "cotangent equation" in the question might be able to be simplified, and using those identities, be represented in a,b,c form.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

If you are familiar with \begin{array}, you can use that the improve the formatting of the code. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Calvin Lin"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/calvin-8u8hog/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Thank you, I have edited! But it is still tiny when inserting fractions, what should I do?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Don't use \mathrm."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Use \cot, \cos, \sin etc for the trigonometric functions. I've edited your first line as an example.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We observe "},{"type":"text","text":"Kishlaya's Identity","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" closely and make use of the MacLaurin Expansion of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log(1-x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{n=1}^\infty \sum_{m=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{m{n+m \choose m}} = -\log(1-x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \sum_{n=1}^\infty x^n \left(\sum_{m=1}^\infty \frac{1}{m{n+m \choose m}}\right) = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{x^k}{k}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
On comparing the coefficients, we can conclude the following
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{m=1}^\infty \frac{1}{m{n+m \choose m}} = \frac{1}{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \sum_{m=1}^\infty \frac{(m-1)!}{(n+m)!} = \frac{1}{n.n!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \sum_{m=1}^\infty \left(\prod_{k=0}^n \frac{1}{m+k}\right) = \frac{1}{n.n!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
And thus, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(n) = \frac{1}{n.n!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(I'll leave it as an exercise for the reader to compute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by other method(s).)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, we compute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q(n) = \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{P(k)} = \sum_{k=1}^n k.k!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
We can telescope the above sum as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow k.k! = ((k+1)-1).k! = (k+1)!-k!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow Q(n) = \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{P(k)} = \sum_{k=1}^n (k+1)!-k! = 2!-1!+3!-2!+\ldots+(n+1)!-n!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
And thus,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow Q(n) = (n+1)!-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Therefore, we are just left with computing
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q(2015)+2015 \pmod{10000} = 2016! + 2014 \pmod{10000} = \boxed{2014}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            No, by taking "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{\pmod{10000}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", I mean exactly the same i.e. the last four digits. It doesn't makes any difference.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I used Jon Haussman method to solve , enjoyed this question , we are able to see this-"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(n) = \sum_{m=1}^\infty \left(\prod_{k=0}^n \frac{1}{m+k}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P(n) = \sum_{m=1}^\infty \dfrac{1}{m\times(m + 1) \times(m+2)\cdots(m+n)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P(n) =  \sum_{m=1}^\infty \dfrac{(m-1)!}{(m+n)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P(n) = \dfrac{1}{n.n!} \sum_{m=1}^\infty \dfrac{(m-1)!n!(m+n - m)}{(m+n)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P(n) = \dfrac{1}{n.n!}  \sum_{m=1}^\infty \dfrac{(m - 1)!n!}{(m+n-1)!} - \dfrac{m!n!}{(m+n)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P(n) = \dfrac{1}{n.n!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[Q(n) = n.n!]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" Q(n) = (n + 1 - 1)n! \implies (n+1)! - n!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" Q(2015)  + 2015 = 2016! - 1 + 2015 = 2016! + 2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I think it was not necessary to take mod , we can directly say 2016! will have many zeros so the last four digits of it will be 0000 and adding 2014 we get the last four digits as 2014.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The above series simplifies to"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac {1}{1.2.3.....(n+1)}+\frac{1}{2.3.4.5.......(n+2)}....."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"multiply and divide by n."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac {1}{n} (\frac {n+1-1}{1.2.3....(n+1)}+\frac{n+2-2}{2.3.4......(n+2)}...)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"this is a telescopic series and thus we get "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[P(n)=\frac {1}{n.n!}]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After that the next part is easy."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(n)=\sum\limits_{m=1}^{\infty}\left(\prod\limits_{k=0}^{n}\frac{1}{m+k}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\qquad\;\,=\sum\limits_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n}\left(\prod\limits_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{1}{m+k}-\prod\limits_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m+k}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\qquad\;\,=\frac{1}{n}\prod\limits_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{1}{1+k}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\qquad\;\,=\frac{1}{n\cdot n!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q(n)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}k\cdot k!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\qquad\;\,=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}\left((k+1)!-k!\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\qquad\;\,=(n+1)!-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q(2015)+2015=2016!+2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has more than four trailing zeroes, the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{2014}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1/ P (n) = {1, 4, 18, 96, 600, 4320, 35280, ... , 2311256907767808000, 48658040163532800000, 1072909785605898240000, ...} Sequence can be formulated for finding all terms; "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r = n + 1/ n + 2; 1/ P (n) = (n)(n!)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Q (n) = {1, 5, 23, 119, 719, 5039, 40319, ..., 121645100408831999, ...}"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[Q (2015)] = [Q (21)] = 9999"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9999 + 2015 = 12014"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[12014] = 2014"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large \\sum_{d|2016} \\mu(d)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\mu"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the "},{"type":"text","text":"Möbius function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" and the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the positive divisors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can apply a fundamental result of the "},{"type":"text","text":"mobius function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":". Specifically, if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{d|n} \mu(d) = \boxed{0}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The proof is as follows.  Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = p_1^{\alpha_1} \cdot p_2^{\alpha_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot p_r^{\alpha_r}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha_i \ge 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all i =1,...,r). If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" d|n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" d =  p_1^{\beta_1} \cdot p_2^{\beta_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot p_r^{\beta_r}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \leq \beta_i \leq \alpha_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for i = 1,...,r.  If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta_i \ge 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some i = 1, ... , r , then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mu(d) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \sum_{d|n} \mu(d) = \sum_{(\beta_1, \ldots , \beta_r)/ \beta_i = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad 1} \mu(p_1^{\beta_1} \cdot \ldots \cdot p_r^{\beta_r})  = "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large = 1 - \binom{r}{1} + \binom{r}{2} - \ldots + (-1)^{r} \binom {r}{r} = (1 - 1)^{r} = 0."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's another proof that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle\sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 1."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that sums of arithmetic functions on divisors are multiplicative. Therefore, if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = p_{1}^{a_{1}} p_{2}^{a_{2}} \cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle\sum_{d \mid n} = \displaystyle\sum_{d_{1} \mid p_{1}^{a_{1}}} \mu(d_{1})  \cdots \cdot \displaystyle\sum_{d_{k} \mid p_{k}^{a_{k}}} \mu(d_{k}). "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" However, note that any term of the product is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since all terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mu(p^2)= 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \mu(1) + \mu(p) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so we are done."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 01 Level 1 or 2?

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/oYLpPevie7-untitled.png?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the distance traveled by bus before the man board on it.Let "},{"type":"text","text":"t","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" be the time taken for it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Displacement of man"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 48+x=10t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"           ------"},{"type":"text","text":"(1)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Displacement of bus"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" = x= \frac { 1 }{ 2 } \times 1\times { t }^{ 2 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"         -------"},{"type":"text","text":"(2)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using "},{"type":"text","text":"(1)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"text","text":"(2)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":","}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t=8s","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"text","text":"t=12s","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are two time instances because at first the man can overtakes the bus as his velocity is more initially.He could board the bus without overtaking.This corresponds to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ 8 }^{ th }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" second. Then the bus accelerates and its can overtake the man.The man could also board the bus at this instance also. This corresponds to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ 12 }^{ th }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" second."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 02 Level 1 or 2?
When and How Do They Land?
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/EjG0T4FjJA-8869d4fe2957ec8d641dcf158de22b143076c84810443d3eda44a08ddf2b1682.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the top of a tower, one ball is dropped and another thrown horizontally with a velocity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". How will they reach the ground?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assumptions and Details","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Neglect the rotation of the Earth."}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Both situations have an initial speed, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", of 0. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
But let's say that the height is 10 meters     "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can use the "suvat" equations to solve for both.    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the vertical ball: "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} 
v^2 &=& u^2 + 2as \\
v &=& = \sqrt{0^2 + 2as} \\
&=& \sqrt{2 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 10} \\
&\approx& 14.00 \text{ m/s} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And to find the time taken:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} 
v &=& u + at \\
&=& 0 + at \\
t &=& \frac va \\
&=& 14/9.81 \\
&\approx& 1.43 \text{ s} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the horizontal ball, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
there are 2 components therefore it is a different speed "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v^2_{x}=u^2_{x} + 2as_{x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" horizontal component. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v^2_{y}=u^2_{y} + 2as_{y}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" vertical component."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            But I wrote it as "will reach the ground". It has the same meaning as "about to strike", right?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I think the question is worded poorly. As I recall in school the always used the term "just before striking the ground" This prevents the confusion that the object stops when it hits the ground. Both objects stop when they " reach the ground!"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nothing was said in the problem as stated about ignoring the Earth's curvature.  The ball with horizontal component will reach the surface later and at a greater speed.  In order to meet the criteria of making an accurate scientific statement, be very careful to be precise in your wording.  That said, there was also nothing said about the initial speed and that could be stated as being great enough to escape Earth's gravitational field, in which case that ball would not only not hit the ground, it would be on its merry way into the solar system.  Where is unimportant.  I want a credit for the "Oops" I was given, when in fact I was correct based upon the available information.  Admittedly, I limited the horizontal component so that ball would also strike the surface.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Considering that there's no air resistance and ignoring the curvature of the Earth, yes, they will reach the ground at the same time."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there's air resistance they experience different magnitude of air resistance depending on the medium they travel.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            so you want to say if i drop bullet from 10m and in same time i shoot bullet horizontal two of thouse bullets will hit ground at same time"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Calvin edited the comment.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: Roots Both Ways
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large y =\\sqrt { x+20160 } -\\sqrt { x-20160 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many solutions exist for the above, such that both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"text","text":"integers","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: General Diophantine Equations - Problem Solving","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m,x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are integers such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{x + 20160} - \sqrt{x - 20160} = m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then certainly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,m \in \mathrm{N}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", while "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x \ge 20160"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \le \sqrt{2 \times 20160} = 2\sqrt{10080}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, on squaring,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{array}{rcl}
2x - 2\sqrt{x^2 - 20160^2} & = & m^2 \\
2x - m^2 & = & 2\sqrt{x^2 - 20160^2} \\
(2x - m^2)^2 & = & 4\big[x^2 - 20160^2\big] \\
4m^2x & = & m^4 + 4\times20160^2
\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be even, and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be even. Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m = 2n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \in \mathrm{N}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n^2x \; = \; n^4 + 10080^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must divide "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10080"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence we must have
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x \; = \; n^2 + \big(\tfrac{10080}{n}\big)^2 \qquad \qquad m \; = \; 2n "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
for any positive integer divisor "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10080"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \le \sqrt{10080}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10080 = 2^5 \times 3^2 \times 5 \times 7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6\times3\times2\times2 = 72"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" positive integer divisors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10080"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10080"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not a perfect square, exactly half of these are less than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{10080}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac{72}{2} = \boxed{36}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solutions in integers to this equation."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            This is a much more detailed and rigorous version of what I did. Very nice! :D +1

title: This year's divisors
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the mean of all positive divisors of the number 2016?"}]}]}
